newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: Prospect of benign CPI sparks NZ debt mkt rally.
newsitem.headline: Prospect of benign CPI sparks NZ debt mkt rally.

text.p: Figures in brackets compare against previous day's close
FUTURES PHYSICAL YIELD (PCT)
90-DAY BILLS (JUN) 92.25 (PREV 92.16) 90-DAYS 7.57 (PREV 7.65)
OVERNIGHT CASH 7.35 PCT (PREV 7.40) US 5-YR 6.84 (PREV 6.77)
* NZ debt rallies at close as hopes grow for benign inflation data on Tuesday
* Strength comes across curve, shorts helped by firm TWI
New Zealand debt performed an impressive about-face during Monday's session to close stronger across the curve, boosted by bullish sentiment ahead of Tuesday's key inflation data.
The 90-day bank bills rallied eight basis points to 7.57 percent and the June futures contract closed up nine at 92.25 on good volume of 3,337 contracts traded.
Dealers said the short end was finding support through the currency's Trade-Weighted Index, which continued to hold in well above 68.65.
Hopes had risen that annual core inflation would be a benign 2.2 percent or less, following December's 2.6 percent.
Bonds also gained on the improved inflation expectations, with good offshore buying in the 7/98s and local buying in the 03/02 maturity following a bearish open in line with weaker U.S. Treasuries.
"The way the market's acting in the futures it looks like a bit of a short squeeze, or some position-adjusting going into the CPI tomorrow," an Auckland dealer said.
A Reuters poll of economists gave an average forecast of 0.41 percent quarterly inflation (2.16 percent annually), against the Reserve Bank's of 0.5 percent (2.2 percent).
The tightness of monetary conditions beyond that assumed by the RBNZ in March -- a mix of short rates at 7.5 percent and the TWI at 68.0 -- lent traders confidence to buy.
Several commentators have suggested that if market players do not ease conditions sufficiently on the back of a good core inflation number, the RBNZ may step in and do it for them through a comment.
Dealers said a quarterly out-turn on market expectations of 0.4 percent might spark a rally of 15 basis points in the 90-day bank bills, but the currency's reaction would be muted.
One dealer said surprisingly strong data would leave the currency well bid and monetary conditions excessively tight, which would limit weakness in the money market.

"So really you can't sell off too far in interest rates, or otherwise I imagine you would see something come out of the Reserve Bank if conditions tightened up further. I guess that's why people have had the confidence to come in and buy," he said.
